Coordinate Systems

Components in wxIFM are really just rectangles, but they follow the box model. This means that there are conceptual rectangles within a component: the background rectangle, and the client rectangle. wxIFM refers to these different rectangles as Coordinate Systems.

The current coordinate systems are:

  • Absolute: The actual size of the component including everything
  • Background: Area in which the component can draw its background. Excludes border widths.
  • Client: Area in which a component is allowed to place children. Excludes margin and border widths.
  • Floating Window: The size that a floating window would occupy around a component
You may request a rectangle from a certain coordinate systems for a component using wxIFMRectEvent. This event can be used to set rectangles for coordinate systems as well.

Converting between coordinate systems

You may convert from one coordinate system to another using wxIFMConvertRectEvent. Specify what coordinates you are converting to and from using the constants below.

Hit Testing and coordinate systems

wxIFMHitTestEvent is used to determine if a given point is within a given component. You must specify a coordinate system in this events constructor, which lets you hit test only the given coordinate system.

See also:
IFM_COORDS_ABSOLUTE, IFM_COORDS_BACKGROUND, IFM_COORDS_CLIENT, IFM_COORDS_FLOATINGWINDOW
